description: In the heart of Russian : a total gem ! Wonderful service, very good wine selection and good good vibe :-)))
author: Arnaud M.

description: Oh, my - i have found heaven in a wine bar.  This place is so cool.  Great wine pour - kudos to the bartender on duty the night I dropped by - great music also - they play records - and seems to be a lot of locals coming by to drink, chat and hang.  This place is not large but so comfy and great wine selection, good prices and just perfect.  So happy I spent time here and I will return.  Thanks also to the cool bartender.  He was super nice and welcoming.
author: Lauren A P.

description: Cozy nook, great place to have a glass of wine and a conversation. Tender is a great guy and very quick to help.
author: Cole S.

description: This place is tiny, but I really liked it. Maybe because it was so small. It's so tiny, that you can't help but talk to other guests and everyone's been really friendly. If you're lucky and get a seat on the couches, there's no real reason to ever get up again, except for getting another glass of that delicious Rose I've tried. Light, not too sweet, but still smooth - perfection! Well deserved 5 stars.
author: Katja S.

description: Trevor was friendly and awesome! Wine was lovely. Place is cozy, and intimate. All around neighborhood gem!
author: Raquel L.

description: A lovely and intimate wine bar in Russian HIll.  This is a great date spot as the ambiance of the place really sets a romantic mood with the lighting, seating, and chandelier.  They have a great wine list to explore and you can bring in outside food from some of the cute restaurants nearby.  I came here with my boyfriend and his friend and started at the two lush couches in the front.  It made for an intimate location for us to chat, eat some pizza we brought, and watch people walk by.  After finishing up the food we moved up to the bar and conversed with the bartender who was very friendly and as well as other bar goers.  Definitely a spot to check out if you're looking for a romantic drink.
author: Stacey C.

description: Amazing wine selection and vibe. Perfect for an afterwork drink, intimate conversation, friends, family or date. They made the most of the little space with a beautiful walnut bar and perfect decor. Two little brown leather sofas in window are comfy and get snagged early and I got a chance to relax in them w my friend-get there earlier for them otherwise there's plenty of bar seating. Restroom is clean and updated which is a plus in the city! Most of all, Trevor was so personable and poured perfect tastes to my liking and had impeccable knowledge on what was offered. I had a great experience and will definitely return!
author: Michelle S.

description: Very tiny place. The girl that was there seem impatience when we were deciding. Overall it's still a nice place.
author: Donna D.

description: Small wine bar, probably can't sit more than about 12-14 people. Friendly service, good music on the record player, what more do you need? Nice place to stop in before or after dinner in the neighborhood.
author: J F.

description: I'm a wine guy. So there's that. This is a block from my house. Always have solid wine. Oh don't understand. Finding decent wine by the glass is really really difficult. Fortunately Hyde is a special street. The staff is courteous and knowledgeable. The space is awesome. What more do u want.
author: Andrew E.

description:
Stopped in two nights ago. I was out taking an evening walk, and popped in. It is TINY. But I consider it a "destination" stop. There are maybe 8 seats total. A really wonderful wine selection. I think they have sake too. I asked about a wine - the bartender offered a "try". He's knowledgeable about wine, and the vibe is so friendly. Everyone else in there knew each other. 

Quiet, comfortable, really nice wine, uncomplicated, relaxed. As good as it gets. Next time in San Francisco, I'll go back on purpose.
author: Carol M.

description: Great find! Met some friends for a drink before dinner reservations down the street. Tristan kept me company with great conversation while I was waiting for my friends. Cute and cozy space to relax and enjoy some delicious wine. I definitely recommend and will be back!
author: Kathryn G.

description:
You know how people say they have their local date spot? Well friends, this is mine (along with a few others in North Beach when I'm feeling casual ;)

I stumbled upon Bacchus with my really really cool college friend who also happens to be my neighbor and fellow yelper (Hi Paws) and we were immediately floored. Although the space is small, it has a very sophisticated yet hipster vibe to it. We pulled up a seat at the bar and ordered some Prosecco and Viognier. The bartender made great conversation with us and we loved how he had a 90s hip hop play list. The people are very friendly judging by the fact that a few people randomly chatted us up.

Even though it is a bit of a hike up the hills--burning calories for Bacchus is worth it because you will be savoring their sweet sweet wine.
author: Shana B.

description: A nice romantic wine bar nestled in Russian hill. The bar is small and cozy. There was a decent selection of wine with lots of Pinots. A glass of wine ~$12-14 and bottles starting around $50-60.
author: Jay H.

description: Great location and small intimate vibe on the inside. Would love to come back with some friends and lounge in the sofas!
author: Nathan B.

description:
Adorable wine bar in Russian Hill! I live across down the block so I end up here a lot when I'm debating on which wine bars to bring friends to. It's also a fantastic place to go have a pre-drink if you are waiting for a table at Elephant Sushi. 

The owner/servers at this bar is extremely friendly and helpful. 

Keep up the good work guys!
author: Jennifer F.

description: OK, it's rare that I actually drink wine here, because the cocktails are actually pretty good. Plus, it tends to serve as a meeting place or stopover on the way to or from dinner, and it serves that purpose wonderfully. The un-pretentious bartender is a rare plus for SF wine bars. I don't really care if he's the world's best sommelier or not, I don't come here for viticultural education.
author: Angela K.

description:
I love this tiny little wine bar! 

That's all I have to say about that.
author: Kate T.

description:
Small space - can probably only fit maybe 20 in there comfortably. The wines were definitely delicious, but not a very big space. 

Protip: get there early and get a spot, or just get lucky. The wines that I had tried were delicious so try a few.
author: Nina Y.

description: I want to be VIP at this place. It's super small and can get crowded quickly but what a wonderful place to enjoy a glass of wine while listening to Wu-Tang (if you're lucky). You can tell it's a neighborhood wine bar for a lot of ppl and it's nice to see the interaction between the regulars and the bartenders. Def recommend for a first date except you may not get seating so arrive early or late.
author: Pawanpreet G.

description:
I'd been waiting for a chance to visit Bacchus. From the outside the wine bar looks adorable and date worthy. Upon entering, the inside does not disappoint.

To get a seat (since there are around 15), the date gods have to be on your side. We lucked out and found 2 spots at the bar. The wine choices were good, a little more $ than the average glass ($12+) but that may be in part to the high quality of the bottles. I got a Riesling and loved it (I prefer slightly sweeter ones).

I am a fan of this spot.
author: Rachel R.

description: This review is has to do with the wonderful peeps at Bacchus that serve Thrive juices (a drink of the gods that they modestly refer to a Almond Joy). Was on  Polk st, on my way back from a bike ride when I decided to ride up the 17% grade on Union to get my Thrive on. Most of the drinks looked really good, and in the face of a difficult decision making moment, I went with the Almond Joy. I also found that Bodie (sp?) is the owner of 20 Spot (what I consider as one of the Mission's best kept secrets). Go check these guys out, you won't be disappointed.
author: Vivek N.

description: A bit small.  Reminiscent of wine bars in NY.  Narrow, limited seating, single sommelier.  Prices are pretty steep, but they do offer great wines and do the wines justice with some great glassware.  Would come back again, although may come off to some as pretentious.
author: David C.

description:
I've been wanting to try this wine bar for a while and I was finally able to convince a friend to try it out with me last night.

It's tiny. The place maybe seats 10. If you're inside, it's a huge plus making everything seem more intimate and cozy. If you're outside, it sucks because the bar is already full and there's nowhere to sit.

Wine list by the glass is pretty small but well thought out. They have a much more extensive list of wines by the bottle. Since there were only 2 of us, we went with glasses. My friend had a glass of the Riesling and I had a glass of the Tempranillo. Both were very good! 

Can't wait to return!
author: Rachel E.

description:
Bacchus is great!  Amazing California red wine selection with an emphasis on Pinot's.  Make sure you try the Joyce Kelly Cab Franc if you like a little spice.  This place has been open for over 13 years and opens at 5 pm everyday.  The whole staff is pretty cool and super chill.  They play everything from jazz to hip hop to international music.  These guys just opened up a new place called 20 spot which is in the mission but this is a gem that you just can't pass.  One of San Francisco's (un-tapped by tourists) classic bars.  It runs right along the Hyde street cable car too.  

Average glass is between $10-$14 and they have half glasses too.
author: Benjamin E.

description: Cute, small, quiet. Great for a weekday happy hour (a lil on the pricy side, however).
author: Mel G.

description: This is what I picture all wine bars should be.  Intimate but not intimidating with a great selection of wine served by a bartender that wants you to like what you drink.  Overall a perfect spot to drink before or after dinner or both (which we did).  I hope their rent is low, as I don't know how they possibly can stay afloat with so little square footage.  Here is to hoping they make long enough for me to visit again when I am back in San Francisco.
author: Tyler L.

description: I can't imagine that anyone wouldn't find this little gem adorable, cozy, and worth returning to over and over again. Great service and excellent wine. It feels like you've ducked into a cute wine bar on a side street in Paris.
author: E. N.

description:
If you love pinot noir, or if you have a reservation at Frascati, this place is a must. They have a gigantic menu of pinot noir by the glass, much of it local, of course.

If you can, grab the couches by the window. You get to watch cable cars roll down the street while you chat with your friends and enjoy a great glass of wine.
author: Ellie P.

description:
In a perfect world, this place would stay exactly the way that it is: very wide wine selection and knowledgeable staff who will help you pick something outside your usual comfort zone, delicious small plates, overall incredibly friendly bartenders and wait staff, two blocks from my house, and mellow enough to have no wait for 2 on a Saturday night. 

Unfortunately, the business volume probably needs to kick up a notch if they're going to stick around, so I will join the bandwagon on singing the praises of 20 spot on yelp. The restaurant is certainly off the beaten path and a little bit difficult to spot (no pun intended), since they opted to keep the (super cool) vintage neon record sign outside of the restaurant, the signage for the restaurant is subtle enough that it's probably tough to draw people in off of Mission and Valencia. Hence, great place, not that busy as of yet. But do yourself a favor and check it out, best wine bar in the Mission in my opinion.
author: Katherine M.

description:
Great pre or post dinner wine bar. Adorable, memorable, comfy. 

Worlds away from the post-college crowd down on Polk....
author: Noah B.

description:
The word on the street is all the law school students escape to this place.

Once you get here it is obvious why.

They have a decent selection of wine & beer

but I'm suspecting its the casual lounge-y vibe it carries throughout the 

dark dim room.
author: Jennifer C. L.

description: I love this place, personal, unique and just perfect for grabbing a couple glasses of wine on a Sunday afternoon.
author: Sabrina J.

description:
This is very much a neighborhood place - with a twist; it's small, relatively sophisticated and somewhat hidden.  And, that - in addition to  the incredibly knowledgeable bartender (who - to his credit - traffics more in knowledge than pretension ) - makes this a gem.

Imagine a place that has seating for only 9 - at best - and can accommodate only a few more standing; add to that good wines, a great vibe and sufficient visual stimulation indoors and out to complement conversation  - and you've got Bacchus.  

That corner of Hyde and Union sees not only the cable car, but is tree-lined and pleasant - only moments from the Hyde-street restaurants (sushi, Spanish, Continental), if that's your destination.

This is a fantastic place to either begin or end an evening with a date - intimate and unique; it's also ideal if  you want to enjoy a glass of vino away from the noise that can be Polk Street - and to exchange ideas and converse with a buddy or galpal.
author: Blue S.

description:
I stopped in here for a glass of champagne following a dinner date at Luella. I had walked past it a few times before, but I was glad to finally stop in for a drink.

I'm not going to talk much about the champagne, because we only had a glass here, and we'd already polished off a bottle of wine at dinner.  I don't think I could reliably critique based on the drink I was poured. I finished it, and I recall thinking it was reasonably good.  A new bottle was opened for us, and the cork was allowed to pop, so that was fun.

This is a really intimate place with room for 10-15 people.  There are coat hooks beneath the bar.  It was also St. Patty's Day, and it didn't appear that anyone had escaped from the Marina to here.  What more do you need?
author: Brad C.

description: A tiny little wine bar but pretty nice! Grabbed a glass of wine here while we waited for a table at Elephant Sushi down the street. It's pretty small so don't come with a large group.
author: Samantha B.

description: This is a great little wine bar. Super cozy, cute space and friendly bar tenders. I've had the red wine flight and I loved all 3 wines. They will also let you create your own flight which is pretty awesome. They tend to poor heavy too so you definitely get your $$ worth for the flight. I plan to make this one of my regular hang out spots.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
We stopped in here last night looking for a cozy neighborhood spot, and to have some good wine. Mission accomplished!

We also were lucky enough to meet some fantastic people to chat with, and to meet Bohde (I may have spelled that wrong-sorry!), the very cool and laid-back owner. 

We recommend this great spot to anyone looking for great wine, atmosphere, and company!

PS- If you look 12 years old, you should be carded, so suck it up and take it as a compliment. ;-)
author: adrienne l.

description:
Great place to impress someone in town or take a date. It's very quaint but feels exquisite inside. 
I recommend coming here earlier like before 7, then walking to a close dinner spot. That way you ensure a seat. Also get the bottle of wine opposed to glasses. Great selection!! I live close by and love to come here.
author: Tyson B.

description:
I was able to take a date to this spot. I tried to score the sofa in front because I've heard that if you can land the sofa it's a "WIN". I was unsuccessful on the Sofa, but I didn't let that get in my way of a "WIN" date night. 

HUGE array of wines. For someone like me, being a newbie, the bartender was very helpful. 

I love the quaint "neighborhood" feel. I'll be back and I sure hope to land the sofa next time. ;)

Thanks for a perfect evening.
author: Brad G.

description: Great bar to have a glass of wine at a reasonable price. Kudos for listing the wines by flavors, not colors.
author: Matt R.

description: A Russian Hill charmer on Hyde Street. This is a tiny(!) wine bar but so cute and cozy. We dropped in for a quick glass of wine after dinner on Polk and really enjoyed it. We got lucky and were able to sit on the couches by the window. I love love love Hyde Street so enjoyed the view. As mentioned, Bacchus is very small, something to keep in mind depending on the scene/atmosphere you are looking for.
author: Brianna M.

description:
I love small, hole in the wall drinking spots.  That is why I love this charming little wine bar in Russian Hill.  

One night, the bf and I had reservations at Luella's but had arrived really early.  So, instead of waiting around in the restaurant, we walked down the street and happened to walk by this place.  It's SOO small - I think my studio apartment is bigger!  However, with its simple decor and neighborhood charm, we entered inside to get some drinks.  

The owner of Bacchus was there and he is SOOO nice!  He has a great selection of wine to choose from and the prices are totally reasonable.  It's a great place to start off your evening or to meet up with a small group of friends for a casual night out.
author: Cherlyn M.

description:
The 1900 block of Hyde is one of the city's more magical stretches of thoroughfare. One of the city's three remaining cable car lines runs up-and-down the block, and Hyde is one of the more tree-lined avenues on Russian Hill. This block boasts one of the city's finer pizza establishments, one if its most romantic restaurants, a great sushi joint, and the original Swensen's Ice Cream Parlor. 

Among all of these gems is Bacchus - small but robust, its list is limited at times, but the selection always offers something to satisfy and enlighten. Seating is often uncomfortable, but the attraction is the staff. the cozy, friendly atmosphere and the location, rather than the room or the wine list. 

You're practically guaranteed a good time with each visit, and the walk to and from Bacchus will put you in a terrific mood.
author: West R.

description:
Came here while waiting for our table at Zarzuela to be ready.

I'm not a wine-o, so my review is more geared towards other Irish pub, pint of Guinness lovers.

I would not recommend coming here with more than 2 other people. The place was probably designed as a garage for a fleet of Smart Cars in its previous life. The bar takes up over half of the place, which really only allows for maybe 10-15 patrons.

The wine was good. And the bartender/owner seemed like a friendly, knowledgeable guy. If you're around the neighborhood and enjoy your wine, I think you will have a pleasant time here with 1 or 2 of your friends.

But for me, it's a little too "classy" for me.
author: Victor C.

description:
This place rocks. I think the bartender was really cool too. Their selection of wine is quite large and if you're looking for something that isn't available, their knowledge is good enough for other choices available.

I plan on coming back here. The atmosphere is chill, with not a lot of people. It's small, but it's perfect in a sense that it's not targeting crazy large drunk crowds.

Nice wine bar!
author: Eric A.

description: Great wine bar, with really nice selection of wines. You can't quite tell from the pictures, but the place is really tiny. Not a bad thing at all, just good to know the place is quite cozy and intimate.
author: Trevor H.

description:
I came here with some friends after celebrating my birthday dinner at neighboring restaurant Luella. 

Cozy little wine bar with interesting swirly seats at the bar. Good selection of wine and the bartender was very helpful and friendly.
author: Helen Y.

description:
I really like Bacchus. I love me some wine, and this place always has a great selection, including some very non-obvious but delicious stuff. The owner and other staff clearly love wine and people and that makes for great atmosphere and conversation.

It's hip but not too hip, and a great place to start or finish the evening. Some great restaurants right nearby, too.
author: Aaron E.

description:
Great teeny tiny spot in the heart of Russian Hill. Situated conveniently near my favorite place (Za Pizza) and not so favorite (the 'ol Laundromat). 

On our way to dinner we decided to stop in for a glass of wine. It was a Monday and it was slow. We were the only people in there for the second half of the glass. It was really nice and relaxing. I loved the laid back atmosphere which is ideal for a little sippage. 

I think we paid about $25 for two glasses of wine plus tip. We both enjoyed our picks, but we are no wine experts. This is a great place to go, relax and enjoy a nice glass of vino.
author: Natalie N.

description: A very tiny pretty bar in a great neighborhood! Friendly bartender, good spot to grab a glass of wine before or after diner!
author: Alice D.

description: Good music, great service, awesome wine. Enough said :)
author: Helen V.

description: Cool small quaint wine bar on hyde.  Really tiny, but has character.  Good service here and great wine beer selection
author: Jay H.

description:
Always wanted to try this place but they are normally crowded.  It is a small place so it doesn't take many to fill this place up.  

We were in the neighborhood early for dinner and had time to kill.  They just opened up so we grabbed a seat at the bar.  The bartender, Matt, was very friendly - you can find him down a couple doors at Luella too as he also work there.

They only have one champagne by the glass but he gave me a taste before I decide, which I really appreciate.  He did the same for hubby after recommending a sauvignon blanc.  

Nice music, good ambiance, not a bad list of wine with some sake.  For bites, there is a cheese plate available.  However, I'm guessing they'll be ok if you brought in food from the restaurants nearby.

A true neighborhood gem.
author: Gloria H.

description: tiny place, comfortable and friendly. great to come in early and lounge around with a nice glass of wine and enjoy good old Hyde street people watching. I like this place a lot...always feel good here.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Very fun cute little wine bar -- the owner/bartender was very pleasant, and sitting in the couches by the window watching the world walk by was atmospheric and provided some very entertaining people watching.

Also, I'd never heard of any of the wines, and the two glasses my friend and I ordered were all excellent!  So top marks for a fresh delicious experience.
author: Tasha D.

description: Cozy neighborhood spot in Russian Hill. Bodhi is super friendly and engaging, and will make you feel right at home. Expect lively interaction with him and the neighborhood patrons.
author: Dan B.

description:
very, very, very tiny.  like the size of a studio.  literally, this place can only fit 8-10 people, if it's lucky.  kind of feels like someone is having a party at his apartment, but he forgot that he lives in a studio.  like dude, there's only room for 2/3 of us to sit.

anyhoo, wine was great.  comfy couch too.
author: Amy S.

description: Bode, the owner knows his wine. So do I. We got along. I'm notorious among my friends for sending wine back due to wrong temp and/or oxidation. Every single wine Bode served was not only a fantastic pick, but also in impeccable condition. Thanks, Bode!
author: Marina S.

description:
Great selection. 
Quality jazz music.
Welcoming and relaxing atmosphere.
AWESOME bartender.... who was willing to stay open for us even though his last customer of the very slow night was leaving and he was about to pack up.
author: Kristyn M.

description: I love this place. It's super quaint and cozy. Great for a date with one or your two best friends. The owner is usually the one poring, so you know you're getting a fun experience. Love coming here for a glass either before or after dinner, and would recommend to anyone.
author: Emily R.

description:
Bacchus Wine Bar hit the sweet spot:  it's bright, honest*, unpretentious, and the owner rocks.

*Honest:  the owner's tastes in wine are definitely Continental.  He's the guy running a wine bar in California who spent his formative wine years sampling in France, thanks to a fortunate turn of life events.  So his great love is the French, more than the California, grape.  He shares this love with his customers.  Yes, he cares about what you drink.  You will not drink crap on his watch.

This is all so lucky for you, if you happen to step in -- especially before or after dinner at Zarzuela a few doors away.

My husband and I discovered Bacchus (and Bodhe, the owner) when we dropped in on a Saturday night.  Because the owner is a low-key guy, and a local, he was pouring that night.  I'd like him on general principle, even if I hadn't gotten to know a bit about his life and the musical tastes while we were in there.  Which I did.

What do you want?  It's an intimate space.  This is San Francisco, not Las Vegas.  If you're like me -- maybe you live here because you don't mind people too much?  Maybe you *like* the occasional conversation with someone you've never met? -- you will LOVE this place.

Say hi to Bodhe for me; and thanks.
author: Anne B.

description: Tiny, friendly little wine bar. We tried two of the recommended reds, which were well-chosen crowd-pleasers. There aren't a huge number of choices on the menu, which is fitting given the overall vibe: cozy and intimate. And, they're willing to stay open a little late if you're taking your time.
author: Rob R.

description: This is the perfect cozy neighborhood wine bar. I stopped by with a few friends and we were greeted by the owner Bodhi. He was warm and very hospitable, catering to our palates and steering us to various varietals until we hit the perfect vino! I will be returning to this hidden treasure more often...
author: Akash D.

description:
BIG FAN!
Stopped in for a glass of sake prior to heading to Okoze for some sushi. The owner was very nice and friendly. I'm shocked to see any poor reviews of this place, in all honesty, this place is a bit small to expect table service, so it makes sense that he serves directly from the bar where patrons pick up their drinks no matter where they are within the room. 
The owner was playing the soundtrack from Up in the Air which was really nice, and he informed me that the paintings are from a local artist that just moved to NY. The paintings are quite beautiful!
I would definitely recommend this wine bar for a small group looking for a place to have a drink prior to dinner reservations at one of the delicious restaurants near by.
author: Emily S.

description:
A shoebox sized place with a decent wine list and VERY intimate atmosphere. If you don't mind sidling up next to strangers, listening to other peoples conversations, or standing at the end of the bar which is practically spitting distance to the bathroom then hey...not bad. 
Its akin to lounging in someone's living room and sipping on good wine, while not actually knowing whose home you are in. Eh. Just like any other Tuesday.
author: Stacy T.

description:
This is a great wine bar.  Great prices, great selection.  The owner has good taste.  The only reason it gets four stars instead of five is the size - it's really small.  Which is actually something that I really like about it, but at the same time it can be kind of a bummer when they are a little full and you were hoping for a place to sit and catch up with someone over a glass of wine. 

That being said - the wine gets five stars, the ambiance - five stars.  The service - five plus stars!  This place is a winner.
author: andrea w.

description:
Named after the Roman god of wine, this cozy little spot is a perfect date spot.  

Not that I'd know.  I just hope every time I walk by.  ;)

Seriously though, if you can score the couch in the front window then it's a WIN.  I'm always impressed by the array of great wines and the knowledge of the bartenders. 

This is the essential neighborhood spot.
author: Lauren C.

description: A very, very tiny neighborhood wine spot. I have come here a few times, but wouldn't recommend having more than 4 total in your party. Theres a small bar with about 6 seats, a tiny ledge to stand by and set your drink down on the side, and 2 couches in the front that seat 2 people each. The wine list is nice... not too much variety for by the glass, but all of the wines I have tried here are very good. I have yet to be disappointed. I just wish this place moved into a bigger spot. I get that its vibe is the cozy, local wine spot, but it's tough to ever feel comfortable when you're crammed in with the rest of the people here. I guess you just have to hope you get lucky with a seat, or go somewhere else if you can't. Staff is lovely, decor is simple. I feel like this place could use a little rearranging to fit more people somehow.
author: Ashley D.

description:
A small group of four of us just had some sushi around the corner but wanted a bit more wine and sake to tuck us in for the night.  We walked across the streetcar tracks to this lovely gem and were welcomed in by the owner and his friends that were celebrating his (the owner's) birthday.  

Some highlights:

1) Wine/Sake Menu is pretty awesome.  Best Temparanillo I've had in the city so far.  Awesome burnt/chocolatey aftertaste, smooth and a nice pour.
2) Awesome music. Yep, it was Pandora but the mix was great.  (Anything that starts with Radiohead is gonna rock).
3) Friendly service/ambiance.  The lighting/decor is simple and cozy.  The service was great.  I felt as if I had stumbled into my local that I'd been visiting every Saturday night for the last decade.  That's pretty cool and definitely one of the reasons that I'll be back.

This place is versatile - it's a "just want a chill glass of wine after work to decompress" kind of place.  Or it can also satisfy your "i want to go out but without all of the fuss of the scene/reservations".

We'll be back...next Saturday? If not before...
author: Emily D.

description:
I am lucky enough to have Bacchus as my neighborhood wine & sake bar. It's a tiny, stylish, cozy cube where one can enjoy fine wines, superior sake cocktails, a well selected cheese plate and even delectable sushi from Sushi Groove just a few doors down. 

The proprietor, Bodhi Freedom (yes, that is his real name)  knows his wines and knows the regulars. It is a happy little escape pod that is like no other in the city. Swirl around on one of the bizarro blue bar stools or snag one of the two leather love seats by the window for cushy privacy. The rotating artwork is always interesting and the small scale makes for intimate times. Do it like Dionysus and groove on over to Bacchus.
author: wendella a.

description:
I love Bacchus. It's my favorite hangout whether I'm doing laundry next door at Missing Sock or I have a friend over who wants to grab a glass of wine before dinner. It's pretty small inside so it's not good for big groups at all, but it's charming which I like. The staff has always been super friendly and very knowledgeable about the wines they're serving...and if you ask, they love to talk about any and everything wine!!! 

I always do a flight of some sort, which ends up being about $18/20 with tip...which isn't bad if I'm getting my buzz on while doing my laundry...eh?!

Perfect spot to hit up before going out to dinner, or if you just want to grab a glass of wine and chat w/ a friend/date.
author: Kristy M.

description:
I love wine. I love everything about wine. I went to college in a wine town where we went wine tasting 2 Sundays a month. Some might say I am some what of a wine snob (I wouldn't say that, but some might). I enjoy wine bars. I frequent plenty of wine bars, in fact I believe that the atmosphere really makes the wine in a wine bar. 

Now that my wine knowledge and experience is out there, I can write a proper review. Bacchus Wine Bar is your quintessential wine bar. Beautiful wooden bar, a few intimate tall tables, knowledgeable staff, late 20's to early 30's crowd. It is great. My friend had a port here that she loved and they let her take home the bottle so she would know what to buy. They sell wine, they talk wine, they serve wine. The space is some what small, but I like it, its intimate and cozy. The prices are average (6-10 per glass) they have something for everyone! 

The hooks under the bar are a definite plus!
author: Jessica R.

description:
Can't finish your drink before dinner at Sushi Groove? Not a problem my imbibing patrons! Let me show you the new and improved, super small, super swank Bacchus Wine Bar. Taking your time, talking to your date kept you from sipping your alcohol? Well, not a problem anymore, just take the drink with you. You heard me correctly, I said TAKE THE DRINK WITH YOU. Only in San Francisco could you pull these crazy shenanigans off! Order your drinks with sushi to follow today! 

Note: May not be legal to have open intoxicants, but in this city, who cares?
author: Michael E.

description: The experience here was everything that I would want out of a wine bar.  I loved the atmosphere.  It's a cozy place: there is really only room for a dozen or so people in there, if that.  I liked the service - that guy definitely knows about wine.
author: Charles C.

description:
Thank you Bacchus for one of my best birthday's ever!

I had mentioned to one of my buddies that I wanted to have a private wine tasting at a wine bar with friends to celebrate my 21+5 birthday. Ben M., as he tends to do struck up a conversation with the bartender at Bacchus one evening with this in mind, which led to getting in touch with the owner Bhode. 

Bhode kindly opened the bar for us one Saturday an hour an a half before it usually opens, so I could have my shindig there. I provided the cheese and crackers, he provided the wine, champagne, port, muscat, etc. He even let me pick the music! The intimate and elegant atmosphere was perfect for nine of my friends to mingle and talk, all with impeccable service and no need to holler to be heard. 

Did I mention they also have those purse/coat hooks under that beautiful wood bar? Talk about a tipping point!

However, don't EVER drive here, getting parking takes FOREVER, and is NEVER close. Besides, drinking and driving is bad. Drinking and taking a cab, not so bad =)

I wish I lived close enough to be a regular at Bacchus, there seem to be several, but I guess it's just as well for my liver and my wallet that I don't.
author: Camille H.

description:
Cute and cozy little space but too bad it's not a larger bar where you'd hang out normally besides waiting for a table at Sushi Grove or other surrounding restaurants.  In terms of the bar itself I'd probably just give it three stars but what's pushing it over to 4 for me are the amazing sake cocktails!  

Very light and refreshing and lethal for me since I wouldn't mind sitting at the bar for hours on end drinking those concoctions!
author: Tanger T.

description: Cozy little wine bar with a decent wine list, great service and friendly patrons.
author: Mimi T.

description:
My friend to Bacchus barista: "I have a broken heart."

Bacchus barista to my friend: "I have syrah grenache."

'nuff said.

[best of all, the bartender had my back when two Marina guys were trying to get me to visit their MySpace pages - what? - while I was waiting for my friends to show; major points to him for that]
author: Anna H.

description: There is too much of the best of San Francisco in this place: intimate setting, friendly service, great selection, and the quiet rattle of the Hyde streetcar line outside. Came late on a Monday and they kept the place open just for us. This spot will definitely impress.
author: Ryan D.

description:
I liked it!

Incredibly tiny/cozy wine bar just a few doors down from Sushi Groove... Bacchus is where SG sends their patrons to *wait* while their table is getting ready.

Very clever.

Intimate wine bar with wonderful selection... my friends and I ordered a bottle of yummy full bodied pinot noir that the bartender recommended and it was perfect. 

We were lucky and scored the 2 comfy couches up front by the window and tucked our legs under us and planted ourselves there for 1 hour after our nice dinner at Sushi Groove... we are so spoiled!

Recommended, perhaps not as a destination because it IS so small, but if you're in the area and you see some available seats do check it out.
author: Nenette Y.

description: I've experienced better.  Good wine list and I like the fact that they offer tastes and full glasses, but I  will not go back.  I didn't get a very warm feeling from the owner and that was a turn-off strong enough that I will not return.
author: Diane W.

description:
If I could pick one place in the city to chill out with a couple of my friends with a few glasses of wine, this would be it. The space is awesome with some interesting characters. 

First tip, if you hang out for 20-30 mins when its busy a spot will open at the bar.  The crowds (i.e. more than 10 people) go in waves, so don't get put off when people are standing by the door.

Bhode is a great guy to hang out with.  As a hint, if you have more than three people, buy a bottle.  They are priced much better than the glasses.  Bhode also has an excellent collection of Oregon Pinot...he's got some gems!

Oh and by the way, Random-Frat-guy-who-had-sex-with-your-date-in-the-bathroom-last-Saturday, you are a sick bastard.  Go back to the Marina or wherever you came from...
author: Tim S.

description: Fun, little (I mean teeny, tiny) wine bar with a decent wine list and comfy/neighborhood vibe. Would definitely come back if I was in the area.
author: Gina C.

description: Place was ok. I've been there before a long time ago when it first opened. Wine list is not that impressive and $15 for an OK glass of champagne? No thanks.
author: Johanna W.

description: Cozy, romantic, and very, very hip, this wine bar caters to a diverse crowd of neighborhood locals and those in the know. The owner really knows his wine and has a great selection, and the ambiance is always just right. This is one of my favorite places to be on a Friday night.
author: Alison C.

description: Figured I should upgrade my review to five stars since my only 'complaint' was the place's size - after visiting many more times, I realized that I quite enjoy the small, intimate environment.
author: Bradley S.

description: Every hood has their favorite wine bar, and in Russian/Nob Hill, this is it!  Intimate setting, perfect to enjoy one or two beautiful glass(es) of wine or bubbly.
author: HY L.

description:
Wednesday night rolled around, and a girlfriend and I wanted to grab a drink to relax. We both had recently walked by Bacchus, and surprised by it's tiny size and therefore inherent cute factor, we decided to check it out.

We arrived to find the bartender (perhaps owner?) chatting with two gentlemen at the bar. We took two seats at the bar as well, and were handed a wine menu. With my wine knowledge being as limited as it is, I decided not to even venture in to the wine list, which looked massive. I told the bartender that I wanted to try a glass of sake instead. 

After throwing out a sentence about what I liked in sake, he suggested a sake with a cantaloupe finish to it. "Would you like to try a sample?" Yes please! It was fruity and refreshing-- so we ordered two glasses and spent the next hour chatting before we paid and walked home.

This seems like a very mellow place for locals to stop by and have a drink together, as long as its not crowded. The art on the walls was beautiful (but sadly, too pricey for my budget). I would hesitate to recommend this place to non-locals, however, because it could fill up in a heart beat., and thus might not be worth the trek. (I think there were perhaps 7 seats at the bar, and two couches in the front of the room?)

I will be back!
author: Lauren M.

description:
I went here last night with a friend who I hadn't seen in a while.  We sat down at the bar and, by the end of the night, had enjoyed some fantastic wine ranging from a pinot noir to a malbec (or three), to a half bottle of Veuve to a wonderful champagne by the glass to cap the night off.  Bodie the bartender was awesome (if you read this, best of luck with the little one on the way!). 

The atmosphere was cozy and perfect for yesterday's cold, rainy night.  We ended up chatting with another patron sitting next to us, as the place has the feel of someone's living room - casual, comfortable, intimate...kind of like you're at a friend's house.

Tucked away in Russian Hill, it is an adorable and unassuming place to spend the evening, or to spend an hour before your reservation at Sushi Groove South.  I will definitely be back - this might become a regular meeting place for me and my best friend.
author: Lauren S.

description: Cozy little space, room for maybe 15 patrons tops. Decent selections of wines and a small selection of sakes. They closed pretty early taking last call around 12. Pretty interior with an early 30s well-dressed crowd.
author: Jeremy S.

description: I made an unexpected trip to Bacchus last night with my visiting brother and sister-in-law. We had an hour wait for a table at Okoze Sushi down the street, so we hopped on Yelp and found that Bacchus was practically next door. As others have said, the place itself is very very small, but this does add a little bit to its charm. The menu had a pretty nice selection and I found the price by glass very reasonable. The pours were also VERY generous. My only gripe is that the price for a taste seems rather high.  My sister-in-law also tried to order a saketini that they didn't have the ingredients for, which I found a little odd for fairly early on a Friday night. That said, we really enjoyed our evening here and I would really recommend it for a pre- or post-dinner glass of wine.
author: Phillip N.

description: My friend and I strolled into Bacchus just by chance on New Year's Eve. Not knowing that it was closed for a private party, we were hesitant to enter, but the owner, Bodhi, was so very welcoming and warm to us. The wine was great as well as the intimate vibe that carries throughout this small find.  There is literally no room for attitude and it serves as a great place to get to know one of the locals in the hood. Drinking among strangers never felt so good! I can't wait to return to Bacchus.
author: Stacia F.

description:
A very intimate wine bar, with seating for about 15 or so. There are stools along the bar, and two small couches that will fit a group of 4. 

A good place to start the night, but would not stay here for too long. It's not too fun if you can't grab a seat, but if you're able to sit down, it great to sip on some wine and carry a nice conversation. 

Everyone is pretty friendly there, strangers will come up to you and start chatting. So if that's your cup of tea, go for it. 

This place also serves sake and saketinis.
author: Maggie L.

description:
Like many others before us, my friends and I were going to one of the restaurants in the area (this time it was Zarzuela). We had about a 45 minute wait and decided to kill time at Bacchus with a glass of wine. 

I love small cozy spaces, esp. when there are just enough enough people to make it engaging but not so many that you feel smothered. It was perfect. The wine was excellent, a pinot that I had never heard of before. 

A perfect place to chill before dinner.
author: Jenn G.

description:
Pretty small (seating room equal to about 3 photo booths, packed). It can get difficult to enjoy your wine when you're being jostled by neighboring elbows. It's truly fun when you go on a dead evening, but  apparently dead evenings here are not common.

Not one of the larger wine menus in the city. Good thing they also offer sake and beers, and taste portions (half a flight). Their only pairing option is a $15 plate of cheese. The guy working there is pretty chill and cool to talk to. You can also adjust the hydraulic bar stools to accomodate your particular height - or just to adjust your neighbor's and piss the crap out of them.
author: Clar L.

description:
A nice little wine and sake bar with a good level of class but no hot sake--all cold, yes cold sake.

Atmosphere
It's small--less than 12 stools and a few sofa's by the window.  There's a good selection of drinks.  As a hot sake drinker--the cold sake is a bit of a turn off.  The wine list is very nice.  It seems a lot of regulars visit this place.

Drinks
Did I mention they do not have hot sake?  

Service
Impeccable
author: Billy C.

description:
My first ever wine bar experience was at Bacchus last month.  I've tried to avoid these places because of the idea of a bunch of people sitting around talking about how the angle of the sun can affect the flavor of a grape and therefore the wine it produces.....YAWN.....whatever.

I was snobbing the snobs!

However, Bacchus was so not like that.  Its a small place so a group bigger that 4 or 5 may not fit at certain times.  In fact, I think they have one table, 1 bartop, and one bonus counter.  The bottles are well placed for all to see.  Decor is modern but not too out-of-this-dimension futuristic.  It seems dark but you can make out the names on the wine labels.

While I had a few yummy wines, including a great pinot noir, I was most impressed by the service.  I told the bartender that this was our first time.  Not only did she treat us like any other patron but she explained that it was no big deal.  I think her name was Margot.  She was very pleasant and informative and made great recommendations.  I also overheard other guests asking about a male bartender referring to him as a "cool guy who buys the wines personally."

I highly recommend going here.  Its not the biggest room but the atmosphere isn't stuffy at all.  The cable car rumbling by adds charm.  Bartender was very cool & down to earth and the wine list has selections that I want to try next time.
author: Pete M.

description:
Is this the only two-star review for Bacchus?  I'm not sure it's really that bad, but the place needs a bit of balance, a bit of a kick in the pants to think a bit harder about its manner and its ambience, not to mention its wine list.  The place is very small and when I first went in, and saw that they were going for Sake as well, I had high hopes of a Tokyo Golden Gai type of experience.  Unrealistic in retrospect, but the wine list is very short and almost totally old world as far as I could see.  Enjoyed the fizz, riesling, malbec (argentinean, the one exception to the old world rule), but the sancerre tasted empty and the trebbiano had that pub wine kick that starts out good but by the end of the glass is giving you a dry mouth. Gewurztraminer also good, but is it ever bad?  Been there twice recently, and the last time was pretty average.  A loud bunch of people who knew each other well dominating the space (not hard, given how tiny it is).  Kinda hard for anyone else to feel comfortable.  The barman also distinctly standoffish (Standoffish? in SF? shurely shome mishtake).  Went to pay him, and as we exchanged check and cash, he started a conversation with someone who was just getting up to leave.  When you're paying top dollar for a glass of wine (or a few, as you may discern from the list above) you expect a certain kind of interchange, right?  A kind of thanks for the biz acknowledgement of your part in the ritual.  Had I been rude earlier?  A cultural crossed-wire?  I saw someone else with a similar experience further down - perhaps it's related to the particular bartender on duty - owner take note.  And you can't blame the wine-list on one barman - unless he's the owner, of course.

This place ought to be lovely, but somehow, it just misses it.
author: Nick J.

description:
I was surprised by the quaintness of the place. Then I realized how large and accomodating the place was given its intimacy and how Bodhi treats you like family. In my case, that means taking the piss out of me every so often in very funny ways. Great wine selection and the place is PERFECT in size for local restaurant overflow and on off nights (not F/SA), it's got the local flavor which is my bias since I live in RH...

Update: If you like/love Bohdi then you should swing by and congratulate him...
author: Raul L.

description:
I used to live around the corner, frequented the place probably 2-3 nights a week.  It's one of the only things I miss about Russian Hill.

The ambiance, regardless of size, is impecable.  The music is always excellent.  But, its always all about the wine.  I challenge you to find more top-notch Pinot Noir by the glass at any wine bar, or nearly any restaurant.  

Okay, it's also all about the company.  It is definitely VERY local - you'll see the same faces again and again, but also very inviting.

Stop in, introduce yourself to Bodhi and the rest of the crew, kick back with a great glass of wine in a comfortable setting, and enjoy yourself
author: Dave K.

description: We discovered this precious little wine bar when we were waiting for a table at Frascati.  Bacchus was just too cute and the atmosphere is very laid back.
author: Eddie L.

description: I can't say enough good things about this place.  Monique and I walked in here on our anniversary before a dinner at Zarzuela up the street.  Bacchus has a very relaxed feel, no pretensions, and a very friendly vibe.  We had a long wait for our restaurant reservation and my only regret is that we didn't stay at Bacchus longer.  Bodhi, the owner, called the restaurant for us so that they would know where we were waiting.  He floated in and out of conversation with the six to eight customers, and his playlist was just as good as the wine.  One of my new favorites in the City.  Bottom line:  go.
author: Morgan G.

description: Stopped at this place to have a glass of wine while we were waiting for a table at Zazuela. The place is super cozy so we decided to come back after dinner. The owner is really nice and helpful. We had a nice chat about German Riesling and Ice Wine. Love the musics they play here. They have pretty nice long list of bottle selection for such a tiny place. Did I mention that they serve sake too?
author: P. L.

description:
On a friday night I want some quality time with my guy and a little luxury in the form of a local stroll, a really nice glass of wine, good conversation, quality ambience (and quality ambient music) and enough of a scene where I know I left my house and am doing something special but no obnoxious attitude. Bacchus does all that for me and more. 

It's within walking distance to many great restaurants plus ice cream or, if you're in a different mood, laundry. And though many well- groomed and slightly shiny looking people who likely live in the Marina or thereabouts might be seen at Bacchus from time to time, everyone seems to check their attitude at the door and simply enjoy  socializing with friends in a contemporary, cozy, neighborhoody atmosphere. 

Friendliest, homegrown bartender ever.
author: li a.

description:
Went there with my girlfriend and a friend and his wife. We sat across from each other in the comfy couches.  We asked the bartender to give us half glasses of a variety of wines.  After an hour or so went to Frascati for dinner.  We told the bartender where we were going for dinner, so about the time we were getting ready to leave he called up to make sure that they had our table ready.  Quite small and cozy... 

Great place to take a date, or to stop in for a drink before dinner.
author: Joshua M.

description: This is a teensy little bar. The owner is the only one I've ever seen bartending, and tonight he was playing the cd of a friend's band. I now have a new favorite local band. It is an incredibly chill atmosphere, since you're up close and personal with everyone else there. The wine is moderately priced depending on what you like, and overall I think it's a really romantic intimate place to grab a drink with a date.
author: Merrilee T.

description: We loved it!  I looked up this place on my phone after finishing dinner at a near by popular restaurant. Very small, quaint, mellow and overall very relaxed wine bar. Very unique vibe and great wines. I cant remember which wine I tried but it was on the high end of the wines available. I would definitely come back and loved our experience here. Only concern is I could imagine this place becoming very crowded as it is small....
author: Brandon L.

description:
This awesome wine bar is like an upscale Cheers -- oops, am I dating myself? You know, it's the place you want to go "where everybody knows your name."   

The owner knows his wine, and the vibe is neighborly and relaxed.  One night, Za Pizza was too packed so my friend and I just ordered a slice to go and took it up the street to Bacchus.  Yummy pizza and great wine -- heaven!  The bartender couldn't have been nicer about it, and there were many envious stares all around.
author: Karen H.

description:
what do you get when you combine an abundance of great wines, a swank presentation with something teeny tiny and miniature in size. no i'm not talking about myself here people..... welcome to bacchus wine bar.

yesterday was one of those perfectly pretty san francisco days.... bright, sunny, crisp, cold. after a loooong hike around the city (we almost made it all the way out to baker beach!) my friend Aaron suggested we stop somewhere to clink a few glasses of Cab. like I would ever resist that. he knows my weakness..... even though i can barely tolerate his dull company most of the time. i manage somehow. 

i had to run home first to change into more appropriate clothes (perhaps a fancy ball gown or some flashy glittering ensemble? kidding), but Bacchus turned out to be exactly what i had in mind.... who doesn't love a late afternoon stroll down hyde street? the quaint tree-lined streets, the shops, cable cars rolling by. we got there just before the dinner hour so there were a few other people in there sipping wine before (i'm assuming) their dinner rezzies at one of the restaurants on Hyde Street.

this itty bitty little speck of a wine bar is so small you have to get pretty cozy with all the other people in there. its cute though..... simple and elegant with a very chill bartender and friendly vibes. apparently wine makes people social and chatty....   

it seemed to me like there was only room for about 8-10 people in here (?) but I could be off. luckily we got the couch near the window and settled in. after a few glasses of this nice earthy full-bodied Cab (sorry forgot to write down the name of it) we realized neither of us had eaten anything in several hours and needed food because the buzz started hitting pretty quickly....  i wasn't in the mood to get drunk at that hour so we slowed down and Aaron (a guy with brilliant ideas but undeniably average looks. HA) suggested we go grab food. 

we made our way outside and wandered down Hyde Street to see what looked good..... (story to be continued in review below)
author: Michelle I.

description: It's ok if someone hits my foot, but only at Bacchus. Even though the place is small and you often feel as though you are part of the conversation next to you, it is a charming place to begin your evening, or walk out of at 1am. The wine is what is important here and it may be one of the only wine bars in the city to feature local wineries off the beaten tourist path. Lovely place to challenge even the most educated wine snobs.
author: Michelle K.

description: I stay true to my hood.
author: Dee C.

description: A good wine list and a nice cheese plate for munching on.  The wine by the glass selection is a bit limited but the bottle list is like a book.  Order a bottle.  You can also order from Sushi Groove next door if you want some sushi with your wine.  Sushi with your wine.  Not wine with your sushi.
author: apple r.

description: I waited three years to come here.  Why?  I don't know it seemed like it was too "too" or something.  Anyway, it's aiight.
author: T-Bone L.

description: A great neighborhood (wine) bar. It's a really small space but that's one of the things that makes it fun. If you're open to chatting with strangers then you'll enjoy it. Bodhi, the owner and usually the bartender, is friendly and chooses interesting wines. If you hang around late enough he may even do a sake bomb with you ;)  It's also a great spot to have a drink while you're waiting for a table at Zarzuela, up the street.
author: Andrew M.

description:
This place was great!  The by-the-glass wine selection was varied and tasty (as it should be at a good wine bar).  The owner (and bartender) was an excellent sommelier.

My only complaint was that on a rather chilly night the door and window were wide open.  I didn't see why that was necessary.
author: Timothy S.

description:
cute little wine bar - well. its actually more like tiny.  but thats part of what makes it cute i think.  good things come in small packages you know!  
bacchus is great to stop into on your way to or from dinner in russian hill, especially if you need to wait at any of the nearby restaurants.  just duck in there for a glass while you wait.  courteous staff, great wine list.
author: Carolyn B.

description: Very cool little wine bar. Great wine and atmosphere.
author: Becka O.

description: Could this place be any cuter? I want to wrap it up in a little box, put a pink ribbon on it, and carry it around in my back pocket. Ok, not really, but it is pretty gosh darn adorable. They must have some deal with Sushi Groove, because the folks at Groove will call at Bacchus to let you know that your table is waiting. Adorable. Sure, it wouldn't be my first choice bar for a rowdy Friday or Saturday night, but since it's in my hood it's always a good choice for a week night drinky drink.
author: Kristen D.

description: Great atmosphere with only a handful of stools (very comfortable stools though). The selection of wine and sake is very impressive and they have several inventive concoctions. I tried the Lychee based one and the one that basically tasted like a mojito. Both weren't too sweet, but not overally strong. Also had the Ozeki Midori which is standard (and made here in California, actually the oldest sake brewer in the U.S.) but very good nonetheless...
author: Nicolas H.

description: a bizarre conglomeration of upscale crap comprises the decor...thankfully the low lighting keeps you from noticing the bar stools that confirm the existence of pure evil in the universe, although the crotch riding nature of said stools makes this abundantly clear.  Excellent selection of vino though, slung by a knowledgeable staff, and a nice place to wait out the inevitable slowdowns at the various joints down the street
author: Kosuke I.

description: I LOVE this place.  Been going for years.  Its super cozy and they have yummy wine.  And as an extra bonus... excellent food is spitting distance away.  What more do you need?
author: Sherrie P.

description: Great weeknight spot (gets crowded on weekends) when you just want to unwind with a glass of wine, listen to some relaxing music and talk with a friend.
author: Alyssa W.

description: I think the atmosphere of Bacchus is one of its winning accomplishments. I am usually thrilled with the wines they have picked for their by-the-glass options. The art changes so I am on board sometimes and other times, I could give it a pass, but that's what makes it an interesting place, the environment is dynamic. The music is usually playlists from the bartenders ipod or a DJ who is in for the night. I like being able to take my wine down to Sushi Groove. The by the glass options have narrowed a bit, but it makes choosing easy, and gives you a good reason to go back which is why I love this place. Oh and for you new visitors, chances are good that nobody is in the bathroom, just push the door a little harder.
author: Sean Q.

description: Teeny tiny, yes. Excellent wine selection, absolutely. Comfy couch, you bet. B's best quality, however, is its location. Situated right next to a laundromat, it's the best place to wait for the eventual return of those who've left their clothes in the dryers since last week...by the time you've tossed back a few, you're feeling a little less bitter, so really, this mighty little place does its part to promote peace among all Russian hill dwellers dependent on public laundry facilities.
author: Julia C.

description: Cute wine bar in Russian Hill. Love the small space (we were lucky to get a seat) especially the wine racks lining the shelve above the bar. The sampler was the perfect option to try a few wines and everything else looked reasonably priced.
author: Jason B.

description: The frenchies run the place.  The flights are decent here.  The setting is the best part. You can have a nice dinner at Pesce or Zarzuela's and have a drink in a intimate neighborhood setting.  It does not seat many people, but great for dates.
author: Susan K.

description: I love Bacchus! It's a great place to go, especially since I live in the neighborhood.  Cy and Bodie (the guys that serve up the wine) are very friendly, knowledgeable and fun. The place is a little small, but cozy; and the wine is a little expensive, but great! One thing that is nice is that you can sit at Bacchus while waiting for an open table at Sushi Groove... and they will come and get you when your table is ready.
author: harmony z.

description: Great wine bar with best Pinot selection per square foot in the city.  I'm biased because I live a few blocks away, but really enjoy it for evenings in the neighborhood.
author: Jay P.

description: I love Bacchus! Such an adorable little spot to grab a glass of wine before dinner. The bartender is always helpful, and they have an excellent selection of wines. It is pretty small though, but I suppose that's part of what makes it so cozy.
author: Brianne K.

description: i love the intimate coziness of this miniature hyde street wine bar.  If you're having dinner at Sushi Groove a few doors down, stop at the restaurant first, put your name on the list, then head up to Bacchus for a glass (or two, or three) of sake/wine and the nice folks at Sushi Groove will come over when your table's ready - you can even bring you half-drunk glass along for the walk!
author: Katie C.

description: I love the atmosphere of this place. Tiny, cozy, great neighborhood wine bar! Wish the prices were a bit less expensive though. Get there early to grab a spot and don't bring a group. I am always on the search for good bars that are near good restaurants - so you can grab a drink before/after dinner. Go here then walk to Sushi Groove (with your glass!) or Luella or Frascati or Zarzuela.
author: Stephanie I.

description: Why is it that every, EVERY time I go to Bacchus I end up getting drunker than initially planned? The "one drink before Za" turns into "...and let's try the red flight" which turns into "can I have another glass of the Zinn?"  Their wines are great, the playlist is fun, those behind the bar are knowledgable and welcoming, the crowd always feels cozy - never obnoxious.
author: Heather C.

description: This is what a neighborhood watering hole is like when you live in a rich neighborhood, and wine and sake replace beer as the poison of choice. It is really small though.  If it were less crowded it could be really comfortable, but as it was, I had to share a couch with 2 unnamed rain-soaked dudes looking at people's jeans that were riding too low... at our eye-level.
author: Katherine W.

description: Love this mini hideaway on Hyde. This place is miniscule but perfect.  Great cheese plate, excellent wines to try.  Great place to go on a date if you ask me.  The small intimate size with the cable car going by... very romantic.
author: Anna S.

description: A nice place to start the evening out with a glass or two of a good red.  Small but comfortable. Friendly bartender and good people watching windows.
author: Beth G.

description: I'm all about the intimate drinking experience, but this place was just a little too small for my liking.  That said, good wine selection and helpful staff.  Good place for a nightcap after patronizing one of the numerous Hyde St. restaurants (Frascati and Hyde St. Bistro being two of my favorites).
author: Geoff K.

description: Great little spot to grab a glass of sake, vino or beer if you're in Russian Hill!
author: Sarah R.

description: Do you know who Bacchus was?  He was the Roman god of wine and intoxication...get it?  Thus an appropriate name for a great little hidden gem.  A non-pretentious venue, where you can get a great glass of wine.  Can't type cast this place either which was refreshing too.  By the time we left at 730ish, it was filling up.  A little bit too dim for me, but really a nice find to mix it up from your good ol standbys.
author: ERICA E.

description: This is one of the first spots that I went to when I moved into the city.  My wife and I went in here on a Saturday night before dinner and talked with bartender for a few hours and he gave us a free glass of wine and changed the music from techno to Grateful Dead (American Beauty).  We've been back a few times and it's always great as long as you can get a seat.  THIS PLACE IS TINY!  Also, they have Sake-tinis that are really great and pack a punch.  I'm not sure how the Dr. feels about this place....
author: Steven M.

description: Great little wine bar to visit after heading to dinner at one of the many restaurants on Hyde Street,  They have a great selection of wine, and if you are lucky enough to get in there and get a seat it is really cozy and intimate.
author: Jaime C.

description: Small intimate. Great place for a date to have a good glass of wine. They have this amazing Pinot Noir right now by Branborg. 10 dollars a glass but worth every penny.
author: Adam L.

description: it's a small place, but it's cozy and cute!  a cool place to start your drinking adventure, but probably a little too small to stay longer than 2 drinks as i was beginning to feel claustrophobic...
author: Mao K.

description: This is so me.  Write a review of a place I went to once over two years ago.  The setting is definitely cool.  Four stars for that.  I could see how coming when there's nowhere to sit would suck, but if this were my hood, I would know just when to go and still get a seat an enjoy the heck out of it I am sure.  Wine list 3.5 stars -  sufficient variety but I didn't learn anything I didn't already know. Also, being the eonophilanderer that I am, I only stick around or come back to a place more than once if it gives me warm and fuzzies.  If the proprietor takes an interest in me as a client and aims to please, that's almost half the battle.  Did not get that there.  Won't say I would never go back, just haven't been back since.
author: Isa L.

description: I agree with the other reviewers that Bacchus is a great, intimate little space. Sometimes on Saturday nights there is a hot DJ who spins house music, and Bohdi the bartender is always a hoot.
author: Marils R.

description: Great little place to relax and unwind with a nice glass of vino at the end of the day or before your dinner at Frascati or Okoze.  They do have one 4 top so it's not super unsuitable for groups, but I definitely see more solo peeps or groups of 2 than anything else.
author: George K.

description: Definitely a great place to bring a date (as long as you aren't all over each other...that probably wouldn't be kosher) or catching up with an old friend or 2.  Has a very cozy feel and the most people I've seen in here was 8-9, and I think half of them was our group.  Wish I could remember the wine selection, but the ones we had were good.
author: Johnson H.

description: If you enjoy good wine and good SF neighborhoods, you know that Bacchus is the wine bar to hit up. They know their stuff & it's got a very sweet vibe - nice music, interesting artwork, modern bar setting with comfy leather couches, and it's very close to many great dinner spots. If you're looking for a glass or a bottle of wine, they have great selections. They also offer beer and sake and some other cocktails. Thanks Bacchus!!
author: Brian B.

description: A perfect intimate date, but with a crowd it can be a bit of a sweatbox.  We were lucky, we got there early one Thursday night, so had the place almost to ourselves.  The bartender was nice - let us play with his iTunes and listen to whatever we wanted.  The wines were a little meh though.  Not terribly impressed.  The selection of sakes were much more impressive.  For a space that small they sure found a way to cram a huge variety of libations inside.  They even offer a whole page of sake cocktails which sounded delectable.  I stuck to the straight-up chilled variety, but for the flavor-inclined, I would say there's a pretty good chance they're tasty.  Would definitely go back.
author: Anthony H.

description: I really wanted to like this place...  I've passed it so many times and have heard so many great things.  However when my date and I arrived on Sunday for a pre-dinner glass of wine, Bacchus seriously failed to live up to my hopes.  The bartender was sitting at the bar on her laptop, and after giving us our menus she proceeded to ignore us to go back to her computer.  The lights were too bright.  But, yes, the wine was good.  With dimmer lights and more attentive service it would have been a much better experience.
author: J O.

description: awesome, adorable bar where the owner makes you feel right at home.  definitely worth the walk up the hill for a great glass of wine and a nice chat with the owner.  looking forward to going back.  bodhi had great recommendations for restaurants and grocery stores and we were lucky to find this gem of a bar.  it's a must visit.  he knows his wines and sushi!
author: Anjali K.

description: I just happened to stroll past this spot while shopping. Not only is the bar small but the selection is limited as well. I was lucky to grab a corner at the bar because the two sofa's and other stools were taken. I perused the wine list but struggled to find something compelling . The bartender was nice and cordial but he manages everything by himself so be patient. Overall, it was a decent diversion.
author: Paul H.

description:
Not only does the bartender not know anything about wine but when you ask for a recommendation, he says all of the wine is great!  He doesn't bother to ask what you like and hep you to choose something to your liking nor does he bother to refill your glass when you've actually made an uneducated guess and bought a bottle and your glass is empty.  What he does bother to do is take your glass away when he assumes you're done though there is still some wine left...

What is the point of going out to a wine bar when it's more uncomfortable then your living room and doesn't make any suggestions to distinguish something off the menu from the latest bottle of wine you purchased for yourself?

I suspect that those who enjoy this place have not frequented a truly good wine bar and just enjoy getting out of their apt to something nearby.  I'd suggest to try branching out of Russian Hill to enjoy a great wine barn becuase Bacchus isn't it...  Seriously.
author: Brooke K.

description: Took my husband here for his bday before dinner at Frascati.  Great selection.  Owner is really nice.  The sake martinis are delicious too.  It's small so be prepared for that.
author: Janet L.

description: small. small. small. i like it. but, here's the thing. my ideal setting for drinking wine is sitting on a couch with some friends with glasses all around. this place is not that scene. it's more about the waiting for a table at one of the local restaurants or kiling time before meeting up with people.
author: Heidi L.

description: cute and a nice place to grab a glass of wine with one (two, max) friend while waiting for a table at sushi groove, luella or frascati. but does anyone else think the chairs/stools are completely out of place compared to the rest of the decor?
author: Lija H.

description: Small. Decent selection. Friendly staff. Nothing too exciting, but 4 stars because if you're thirsty and need something for dinner or a party, you can buy bottles to go. It's the only place in the area to buy a decent bottle at a late hour (especially if you're not okay to drive, although you'd have to be pretty pathetic to get a DUI in this city)
author: Pfeif E.

description: I've seen this wine bar a few times walking down Hyde, it seemed small and quaint so my friend and I decided to give it a go.  It was cute and quaint, I'll give it that, and the wine was good, so two points there.  Now, to the reason of my 1 star...The bartender was very inattentive, she was texting and reading her kindle the whole time, she never asked us how we were doing or if we needed anything else.  We had to interrupt her to order a cheese plate and she didn't seem too pleased.  We got the most pathetic cheese plate I have ever seen.  There were three cheeses, Carr's water crackers, some dried cranberries, and cashews.  Each piece of cheese was about one ounce, if that, and we were charged $15.  Compared to other wine bars I have been to that would give five cheeses for about $11, this was the biggest rip off I have seen in a long time.  All in all, there are so many wine bars in this city, I wouldn't waste time going here.
author: Sarah B.

description: when at Bacchus, i always feel i'm in a swank little boutique hotel bar (my favorite) where you are forced into close quarters to rub elbows and glasses while sipping wine selected from a diverse menu.  it's intimate and social at the same time.  not only is the wine list great, the sake offered is an added bonus.  a little tip:  hit the market on the corner of Hyde and Union to scoop up cheese and crackers - the owner let's you eat them at the bar:)
author: Tracy E.

description: Bacchus is the one place I always make a point to visit when I'm in town.  With an intimate atmosphere that's casual-yet-upscale, interesting artwork that changes regularly, and a wonderful wine selection, it would be hard not to like this place.  However, the staff is Bacchus's greatest asset.  Bodhi (the owner) is welcoming and fun to converse with, as well as very knowledgeable about his wines and a great resource for suggestions on what to try.  They always offer a fun variety of by-the-glass options as well as great flights if you can't decide what you want.  Considering the wines on offer, prices are very reasonable (and you can even pick up some bottles to go if you're so inclined!)  The ambiance, coupled with warm, friendly service make you feel like you're enjoying great wine at a great friend's place - which, I suppose, you are.
author: Jordan M.

description: I love this place.  So much in fact, that i joined yelp just to write this review.  Its a great spot, great list, great people.  Keep up the good work B.F.!
author: anthony p.
